Executive Summary of Risk Management Plan

Twin State, Inc. 

2206 Old Highway 6

Durant, Ia 52747



1. The Facility Policy:



The owners, management and employees of Twin State, Inc.,  are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia by utilization of proper equipment, regular inspections and maintenance and training of all persons that work with ammonia.  Should an accidental release occur, the facility has orientated the local fire department, and Cedar County LEPC, and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.



2. Facility Information:



The primary activity at the facility is the distribution of fertilizer products. Twin States Inc., facility has one regulated substance at the facility - anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in a horizontal bullet-tank designed for this purpose.  The fertilizer product, anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and used in the process of making anhydrous ammonia-based fertilizers as a nutrient for crop production.

 

Consistent with the compliance guidelines of 29CFR Part 1910 and 40 CFR Part 68, this facility has developed a management system to minimize consequences associated with the process of making anhydrous ammonia-based fertilizers.

 

The facility produces two versions of nitrogenous fertilizer from anhydrous ammonia. 



The first process uses anhydrous ammonia with phosphoric acid (68%, CAS No 7664-38-2). This process utilizes TVA Pipe Reactor technology to neutralize the phosphoric acid with ammonia. The result liquid product is an ammonium polyphosphate fertilizer, NPK: 10-34-0. This product is marketed to retailers.



The second process mechanically blend-reacts anhydrous ammonia with 10-34-0.  This process occurs in a mixing tank.  Water and soluble potash in various amounts (recipes) are used to produce various grades of liquid fertilizer.



Twin States Inc. has Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)

in place and developed emergency plans. This program provides plans and information that will assist emergency responders in the event of accident at the facility.



Finally, the management system provides procedures and plans to assist employees in conductions both routine and non-routine plant operations, to identify potential hazardous situations, and to respond to actual emergencies. 



3. Accidental Release Prevention Program:

The facility is in compliance with the provisions of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia" and our state regulations covering anhydrous ammonia.



The facility personnel are committed to the safety of our employees, public and the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by continually improving policies and practices intended to prevent releases of hazardous substances. In the unlikely event of a release, we have an emergency action plan in place to minimize potential effects.



4. The Worst Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario:



Including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distance for each reported scenario.



The Fertilizer Institute TFI/DEGADIS-generated Lockup Tables were used to perform offsite consequences analysis. The following two paragraphs provide details of the chosen scenarios:



The worst-case scenario involves the catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia. In the scenario, ammonia would be released to atmosphere over a 10-minute period. The gaseous ammonia is released at Class F stability with 1.5 m/s wind-speed. 



The alternative-case scenario involves the release of ammonia over a 2-minute period. The release is assumed to be controlled by excess flow valves, emergency shutdown and/or emergency procedures. Weather conditions are assumed to be neutral.



The facility has taken steps to comply with accidental release prevention.



5. The Five-Year Accident History: 

There

have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia for the covered process in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site.  To our knowledge, there have been no accidental releases that have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, and evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



6. The Emergency Action Plan: 

The facility has:

     A.     A written action plan in accordance with OSHA standard CFR 1910.38 

     B.    Provided state and local authorities and emergency planning and committee right to know information as required under SARA Title III of EPCRA.  

     C.    If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at the facility, the required response action is to evacuate the area of the spill and call 911 and all applicable emergency response numbers listed in our Emergency Action Plan



7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  



Safety improvements are an ongoing process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe practices and operations.  There are no additional specific anhydrous safety recommendations for implementation at this time.  



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



Twin State, Inc. has committed to involving employees in plant activities pertaining to preventing and/or mitigating chemical releases that could lead to an accident/release in the workplace and possibly the surrounding community. 

 

The following provides an overview of the ways employees participate in managing safe operations:

     a)  Development and execution of written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).

     b)  Development and review of Process Hazard Analysis (PHAs) and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs).

     c)  Evaluation and maintenance of training materials.

     d)  Hot Work, Lockout/Tagout and Confined Space permitting, as part of the authorization process.  

     e)  Incident Investigation Team members.

     f)  Participate in compliance aud

its as a team member.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



Twin State, Inc. has compiled safety information, enabling both employer and employees, to identify and understand hazards associated with processes involving chemicals.



The following both describes and documents the measures used to ensure process safety information is current and readily accessible to personnel:

    a)  Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) are maintained and are available to employees and contractors.  

    b)  Operating procedures are periodically reviewed and updated as needed.  When changes or revisions to Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) are required by a Management of Change (MOC), the SOP would be revised at that time.  Operating procedures are located in the Plant office and at T- Reactor site for ease of access for employees.

    c)  Piping and Instrumentation schematics of the ammonia unload systems, ammonia process lines and reactor / blending operations are maintained in the Plant office.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS



Twin State, Inc. has conducted an analysis to identify, evaluate and control the ammonia hazards involved in processing operations at the plant.

'What-If' methodologies were selected to assess the potential hazards and Checklists.  At least every 5-years, this hazard analysis will be updated and re-validated.



OPERATING PROCEDURES



Twin State, Inc. has developed written operating procedures to provide instructions for safely conducting activities associated with hazardous chemicals.  Safe work practices will apply to both employees and contractors.



The following provides an overview of facility's operating procedures:

     a)  The Production Supervisor is responsible for the T Reactor operations.

     b)  Management of Change (MOC) relating to Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) will be authorized by the Production Supervisor.  Piping and Instrumentation schematics will be updated concurrent with MOC authorization.

     c)  Written procedures have been develop

ed for the following covered process operations:

          i. Startup

         ii. Normal Operation

        iii. Temporary Operation

         iv. Normal Shutdown

          v. Emergency Shutdown

         vi. Startup after Emergency Shutdown

     d)  The covered process operations do not utilize emergency-operations waivers.  If there are operational deviations and/or equipment malfunctions, the process will be stopped and concerns immediately addressed. 

     e)  The Production Supervisor is responsible for ensuring SOPs are followed, including personal protective equipment (PPE) use.

     f)  The Production Supervisor is responsible for ensuring replacement-in-kind and equipment repairs.

     g)  Consequences of deviation and Operating limits are found in the covered process SOPs.

     h)  Operating instructions are located at the covered processing area and in the Production Supervisor office.



TRAINING



Twin State, Inc. has developed training that adheres to current operating procedures, emphasis on safety and health hazards, and emergency shutdown actions.



The following provides an overview training measures that are in practice at facility:

     a)  Individual employees are accountable for their training level on any given job.

     b)  The Production Supervisor is responsible for verifying that employees are qualified for the jobs being performed.

     c)  The Production Supervisor will ensure employees have the required knowledge, tools and/or services available to maintain covered equipment.

     d)  Employees will demonstrate their job-position knowledge by written test and/or oral test and skills performance using demonstrations & observations.

     e)  Operator training records will be filed by the Manager.

     f)  Employees will be trained in the following:

          i. Plant Overview

         ii. Standard Operating Procedures

        iii. Emergency Shutdown Procedures

         iv. Emergency Procedures

          v. PPE requir

ements and use. 

         vi. SDS Information

        vii. Permitting:

               1. Lock out / Tag out

               2. Confined Space Entry

               3. Hot Work 

       viii. Overview of Process Safety Management (PSM) & Risk Management Plan (RMP) program requirements.

     g)  Refresher training is provided and documented at a minimum of every three years.

     h)  Contractor(s) will be trained on a plant overview focusing on the covered process potential hazards, on facility safe-work requirements, on PPE requirements and on emergency actions.



CONTRACTOR MANAGEMENT



Twin State, Inc. has developed a management program to ensure contractors working on-site meet facility safety requirements and are knowledgeable of potential covered process hazards.



The following provides an overview of the measures used to select and manage contractors working at facility:

     a)  With respect to contractor selection, the Production Supervisor will validate contractor insurance acceptability.

     b)  Contractors will follow the facility's safety policies and procedures.

     c)  The Production Supervisor and/or designee will indoctrinate contractors and retain appropriate records prior to the contractor starting work.

     d)  The Production Supervisor and/or designee will routinely verify contractor adherence to the facility plant safety policies. 

     e)  Contractor accidents will have an incident investigation. 



PRE-STARTUP REVIEW



Twin State, Inc. has developed and implemented a review process to reduce the potential of accidents during the startup of new or modified stationary sources.



The following provides an overview of the measures taken at this facility for pre-startup review to reduce incident potential:

     a)  A pre-startup review team will be organized to assess and validate new or modified stationary sources prior to the introduction of regulated substances:

          i. Construction and equipment meet design specificati

ons

         ii. Safety and emergency procedures are in place and adequate

        iii. Operations and maintenance procedures are in place and adequate

         iv. A hazard analysis will be conducted on new sources.

          v. Modified sources will meet requirements of MOC

         vi. Employee training will be completed

     b)  Pre-startup review will include a knowledgeable person familiar with the facility and a person knowledgeable in process operations. 

     c)  Piping and Instrumentation schematics will be updated and applicable information added to maintenance files.

     d)  PPE requirements will be amended, as required.

     e)  Emergency action plans will be amended, as required.





MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

Twin State, Inc. has a program to ensure equipment used to process, store, or handle hazardous chemicals were designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of releases.



The following provides an overview of the program used at the facility to maintain the integrity of equipment unloading, storing and processing anhydrous ammonia:

     a)  Mechanical integrity is inclusive of, but not limited, the following:

          i. Pressure vessels and storage equipment

         ii. Piping systems

        iii. Relieving and venting systems

         iv. Emergency shutdown systems

          v. Controls and alarms

         vi. Pumps

     b)  The states laws in place will form the basis of operation and maintenance program.  Equipment deficiencies will be corrected before further use or in a timely manner provided necessary measures are taken to assure safe operation.  

     c)  Ammonia relief valves will be replaced at least every 5-years.

     d)  Ammonia hoses will be replaced per hose manufacturer's recommendations.

     e)  The Production Supervisor and/or his designee will routinely visually inspect equipment when the plant is in operation, documenting maintenance as required.  

     f)  Maintenance records and d

ocumentation will be maintained by the Production Supervisor.  These records will include the date of inspection, inspector name, equipment inspected, description of inspection and results of the inspection.

     g)  The Production Supervisor will assure equipment is installed, operated and maintained suitably for the process application.



HOT WORK PERMITTING

Twin State, Inc. uses permitting to ensure coordination between management, operations and maintenance on covered processes.



The following provides an overview of the measures used for authorizing hot-work within the covered processes:

     a)  A hot-work permit authorization is required prior to initiating work.

     b)  The Production Supervisor is responsible for assigning a qualified employee to perform hot-work.

     c)  The Production Supervisor and/or his designee are accountable for ensuring and authorizing this work.  At a minimum, the permit will contain the following information:

          i. Date

         ii. Description of work that includes identification of equipment to be worked on

        iii. Any needed testing and documented

         iv. Name of employee(s) doing the hot-work

          v. Time permit will expire

         vi. Production Supervisor and/or his designee signature

     d)  Permits will remain at the work site, until the job is completed.  At work completion, the permit will be returned to the Production Supervisor and/or his designee. 

     e)  Unless required for an incident investigation, the Production Supervisor may dispose of the hot-work permit(s) when the job has been completed.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



Twin State, Inc. has developed a system to ensure changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, facilities and/or SOPs do not result in increased risk for accidents.



Except for replacement-in-kind, the following provides an overview of the method used by the facility to manage change for covered processes:

     a)  At a minimum, Management Of C

hange (MOC) will consider the following prior to authorizing and implementing:

          i. Technical basis

         ii. Impact on safety, health and environmental

        iii. Impact on operating procedures

         iv. Timing

          v. Authorization requirements

     b)  SOPs and practices will be updated, as required.

     c)  Process Safety Information will be updated, as required.

     d)  Employees will be trained prior to start-up.

     e)  MOCs will be authorized by the Production Supervisor prior to change initiation.

     f)  MOCs will be maintained for the life of the process in the Production Supervisor office.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS



Twin State, Inc. has developed a process for identifying the underlying causes of incidents and implementing steps to prevent similar happenings.



The following provides an overview of the methods used to investigate incidents which resulted in or could have resulted in a catastrophic release:

     a)  Incident investigation teams will include one person knowledgeable in the process and also include a contract employee, if a contractor was involved in the incident.

     b)  The Production Supervisor will be responsible for this investigation.

     c)  The incident investigation will begin within 48-hours.

     d)  A report will be generated which includes the following:

          i. Date of the incident

         ii. Date investigation began

        iii. Description of the incident

         iv. Recommendation to prevent future occurrences

     e)  Corrective actions will be documented.

     f) Report findings and corrective actions will be reviewed with employees.

     g) Incident investigation reports will be retained for 5-years.  These reports will be maintained in the Production Supervisor office.



EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE



Twin State, Inc. has established and implemented emergency action plans for protecting the plant, public health and the environment.  In addition to major ev

ents, the plan includes procedures for handling small releases.



The following provides an overview of the plan used by facility for emergency situation:

     a)  This facility's emergency action plan includes the following elements:

          i. Procedures to inform the local emergency response agencies of a release.

         ii. Company's First-aid Policy.

        iii. Employee emergency action training.

         iv. Annual review of the emergency action plan; unless stationary source changes dictate an earlier review cycle.

     b)  Twin State, Inc. maintains copy of the emergency action plan at/near the Production Supervisor office.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS



Twin State, Inc. has developed a process to evaluate the design and effectiveness of this safety management system.



The following provides an overview of the audit method this facility uses to assess the facility's safety management system:

     a)  The audit will include at least one person knowledgeable in the process.

     b)  The two (2) most recent audits will be retained and available in the Production Supervisor office.

     c)  Audits will be conducted at least every 3-years.
